content.text: The Fabric team just completed a massive Q1 innovation week and we wanted to share some of the awesome projects worked on. Here we goâ€¦
- bullet lists that contain emojis instead of bullet points
What was delivered and next steps
find a place for emoji bullets in editor roadmap
- Iâ€™ve learned how a combination of simple features could create something cool and innovative. All credits to
Make it really easy for Platform teams to work out why Jira/Confluence/Bitbucket are taking so long to load, without having to pull down their repos and build them locally
What was delivered and next steps
A NPM CLI tool called bundle-inspector, that you can point at a website with source-maps and generate a whole bunch of insight into how much duplication / unused code there is.
- Get Apdex for Atlaskit Website so we can track and improve our components' performance.
What was delivered and next steps -
showing full page load Apdex for Atlaskit website. Next steps are in this
We have very loose definition of Apdex.
- Autonomously measure rendering time of every ADF node in Fabric Editor.
What was delivered and next steps
- a micros service that uses puppeteer for measuring rendering time of a posted ADF document and scheduled pipeline script for uploading benchmark data to

- runtime performance is very sensitive to available cpu and memory, therefore we wonâ€™t be able to reliably use it for performance testing (e.g. fail a branch build if performance get worse). Even running such tests on a same machine would be flaky if thereâ€™s a heavy background process running in parallel. However, for external benchmarking system (micros service) having spikes in performance would not be critical as we could build a performance graph based on average data for a certain period (e.g. last 24 hours) and alert us whenever performance degrades.
create a system that would diagnose problems

â€“ being on a Platform Team, it can sometimes be difficult to empathise with the pain which customers experience whilst using our components and products at Atlassian. Fabric Feedback was an Innovation Week project which looked to visualise public feedback via Twitter, combined with details about how customers are feeling through sentiment analysis.

â€“ a dashboard experience which searches for tweets tagged with Atlassian + <optional query> was shipped. Each tweet was visualised and enhanced with information regarding the sentiment of the customer/tweet using the IBM Watson API, and NER through Stanford NLP (scoring range: -1 = max negative, 1 = max positive). The dashboard accordingly provides filters for tweets by tag and sentiment, as well as overall statistics on how customers are feeling.

never trust/visualise public data without cleaning it first! There were (and still are) many tweets from bots and official Atlassian accounts being captured. One of the next steps for this project is to make it more relevant and clean!

â€“ The Entity Service is a new services that is being built in Media to support a part of the core data model for files. As such, reliability and performance of this service is critical. Lately, there had been a concern around the tail end latency of the service, which I set out to measure and improve.
What was delivered and next steps
â€“ It turned out that the

middleware was responsible for a large amount of CPU usage in the service, which introduced event loop lag, causing elevated tail end latency. I authored a series of PRs to the middleware that were released as express-openapi 2.0.0 and improved runtime by up to 1000X, reducing 99p latency from 273ms to 76ms.
â€“ We learned how to effectively use
to diagnose hot spots in Node.js applications, which will hopefully be featured in a follow-up blog.
We wanted to make creating changesets easier and less error prone
We delivered exactly that, we managed to rewrite all of the changeset creation logic to no longer require asking questions about bumping dependents.

Atlaskit flow packages can generate dynamic documentation from code. Which is super helpful for consumers. On the other hand, editor consumers kept complaining about the lack of our documentation. It's really hard to keep documentation up to date without proper tooling. So, we decided to add TypeScript support to
. Now all TypeScript packages (editor, elements & media) inside Atlaskit will be benefitted from this.
What was delivered and next steps
Recursive types are painful to work with.
: We want to improve the current media-group experience in the editor, there is no interaction at all in the current one + we wanted to provide a nice a grid view and emphasize images
What was delivered and next steps
: we shipped a new react component that contains all the logic to create and manage the grid experience, preview + edit mode.
: Try to get something small into master first, instead of coming up with a very advance solution to a problem, later validate that thing is true, iterate, repeat.
To explore methods and develop tooling to generate documentation from repo source
What was delivered and next steps:

A tool was developed as a proof of concept which walks a repo (Atlaskit used for test) and produces static documentation on every files imports/exports (dependencies). The content was also used to deliver a talk at the Front End Forum around Babel AST.
Many good details about working with Babel AST, and the possibilities for future tooling
Performance improvements to Fabric Elements frontend components by reducing bundle size, introducing code splitting and extracting our components to separate packages.
What was delivered and next steps/Any Learnings/Images
We wanted to make the Node.js stack:
â€” easily add or remove unnecessary features
â€” everyone familiar with express-style frameworks (or koa in particular) should be able to understand what is going on and make changes fast.

â€” while incredible monolith did a lot of work for us, maintaining the apps on it, or on several tools build on top (incredible-runner, terrarium), was quite tedious and required a lot of work. The new incredible should put the focus on the business logic.
â€” with Typescript evolving, we want to detect the issues even before we run the tests.
We have created some of the necessary packages:
to manage the modular config of the service and of the other middleware packages;
to generate or validate ASAP tokens;
to abstract away sending logs and tying requests together;
to drop the long-lasting operations when the connection is dropped;
to add the ability to send metrics and send some standard HTTP metrics.
To find about all the supported features we also created a reference app that demonstrates what is possible. Hereâ€™s how the main file of the reference service looks:

One of the biggest missing parts of the project is an abstracted HTTP client interface plus at least one reference implementation. With this ready, we should be able to start switching the smaller services right away.
Thatâ€™s why we continue the work on
! Take a look at what we do next in this write-up:
And, of course, none of it would be worth it without dogfooding. Teamwork Ecosystem part is going to switch its services to the new stack, starting with

As an effort to make devs more aware of our current Metrics, etc, and stride towards a more metrics-driven development pattern, I decided to build a chat bot which would bring the current Editor metrics pulled from various sources (Redash, Bitbucket, NPM, etc) right into the Editor Room (Yes, it is future proofed, a Slack bot counterpart was built too).
What was delivered and next steps
Both Slack and Stride bots were developed and are configured to ping the room every Monday. The service is running on Macros.

Next step would be to try and make this service a generic one so other teams can hook onto it to extend it and create their own Metrics bot. Also to pair up with our Product Managers to optimise the content in the ping.
It was interesting to learn how to setup a service with Macros and how they work, and also of course setting up an Atlassian App
Design System Tools - ADG sketch plugin versioning script
Weâ€™ve been working on a plugin for sketch to allow designers across all of Atlassian to consume the
in an easy way. Weâ€™re 99% there. We wrote a version script that would allow us to autogenerate an appcast file hooking into Sketchâ€™s auto-update system.
What was delivered and next steps
We wrote the versioning script and the publishing script. They seem to workâ€¦

NPM has really useful lifecycle hooks that you can tie your scripts into. As well as pre- and post- hooks allowing you to wrap NPM commands magically. This allows you to manipulate multiple files during the version step and bump everything in a single commit.
We have an internal static hosting service. Why had I never heard of this before?!
Inno Week Demo: Fabric Elements in the pf-content-service
, the observability/metrics team asked for volunteers to help to evaluate some 3party vendors to replace Datadog at Atlassian.
During the innovation week, I tested 2 possible candidates, Wavefront and SignalFX. It was easy to test (
thanks to Observability team that synced all our metrics which are on Datadog to flow automagically to the new tools
) and I could replicate the same dashboards we have in Datadog on both services which made easy to compare and test.
What was delivered and next steps
Iâ€™m writing a blog post about both services and given the DACI is about to be decided and the most probable to be chosen is SignalFX the next step will be a
session to the Teamwork Ecosystem team and then prepare migration of our dashboards from Datadog to SignalFX.
A lot, could use and learn two new monitoring service providers which I didnâ€™t know before.
Spiking Undo Redo for editor on iOS
Itâ€™s clear that any editing application need an Undo/Redo Manager
What was delivered and next steps
I spiked on various solutions to figure out what is the right solution for the editor team. There are 4 solutions with various pros and cons:
Using the current code from WebEditor
Not able to save the undo versions for new sessions.
Not able to maintain the memory.
Cache various versions of ADF on the client-side
The client-side is able to handle the data.
Cons: Not able to scale for big data. (Copied various big documents increase the space consumption significantly)
Use native Undo Manager on Foundation.
Undo Manager will break ADF into steps, so it saves space.
Able to encode and decode data
Able to copy the undo / redo data between platforms (iOS <-> Mac)
Able to use undo / redo on many platforms and extensions (iOS, Mac, TV, Watch, Extension, Notification)
Need to invest in Man Power
Base on our roadmap and vision for Editor, we could choose appropriate solutions to move forward.
There is no silver-bullet solutions, always has trade-off.
Private npm package search and detail website
Concept-  A easy system to find npm modules that Atlassians has published yet.
What was delivered and next steps
to unlock the whole experience which includes search module and details of the module.
Might add history versions and module rank.
Upgrade Reactions service to new version of the stack
- Migrate reactions service to the new version (Spring boot 2 + WebFlux)

The new stack is an evolution of our existing reactive stack. The current stack is a patchwork of various libraries to make a reactive stack on legacy tech (servlet). The new stack is fully asynchronous from the webserver (Netty) to the framework (WebFlux).Â
Scale better (half response time at p99)
Better reactive library (full backpressure support unlike RxJava 1.x)
Spring boot 1.x is EOL next year
What was delivered and next steps
Reactions service was migrated to the new stack
In the process a bunch of common packages were written to facilitate the process for the next service
Weâ€™ve confirmed that the new stack scales a lot better than the old one.
Better state management for Fabric Elements components
- model Synchrony delta to step generation as a finite state machine, and establish a pattern for clear and maintainable state management
What was delivered and next steps
- Wait for a better library to come along / re-attempt on a different platform
. All Media requests in iOS  libraries through the
class. Though we have an old working version, there are some problems with it:
- it is a monolithic object which is hard to test, because we need to stub the network layer, other tests are not possible;
- as a consequence it has a low test coverage about 40%;

- it does not retrieve credentials leaving it to the caller, however it seems reasonable to have this step in the client because credentials are required to make a request. This reduced a lot of redundant statements.
During this innovation week we targeted to recreate the Media client, make it testable.
What was delivered and next steps
came up with ideas how to structure the client better. We started implementing them during this innovation week. Now the client consists of layers:
â€“ makes HTTP requests with Alamofire. Coverage 100%,
â€“ retrieves credentials and makes a request. Uses HTTPClient to make requests. Coverage 98%,
â€“ makes calls to Media using MediaHTTPClient. Its responsibility is to make a call and parse the data.

In this structure every layer has a single responsibility which makes the code more clear and easier to test. We used network stubbing only to test HTTPClient. Every other layer is tested by mocking the layer it depends on.
that adds a method to retrieve file metadata. We are going to add new functions to the client and gradually switch components to the new client.
Improve Android MediaViewer by removing legacy code and using better internal APIs
This was an engineering health project to remove legacy code from MedaViewer NextGen + use rxJava instead of ResultReceiver
Image Captions are a long requested feature. So, I decided to and build them!
What was delivered and next steps
Refactored part of media plugin for Editor (tech debt)
Click-to-add captions on images within the Editor â€“ supports all inline ADF nodes!
to add captions to document format
Dealing with content-editable bug hell in browsers. Check the second half of

Birdy is the HTTP client written by media which is used across a lot of Fabric. During the Teamwork Ecosystem work on Calendar Service, I encountered a few areas of improvement that I wanted to improve within the library.
What was delivered and next steps:

When making calls to services, birdy requires a list of "acceptable" status codes to recieve in response. For services that need to catch all, or a range of codes, this gets cumbersome. It is now possible to provide a callback to verify the code:
Automatic gzip and deflate response handling.

Webservices often send back payloads uysing gzip or deflate compression to reduce transfer size and times. Birdy can now implicitly handle these payloads, decompressing them for your invisibly (with the option to not decompress if you wish to work directly with the compressed stream).
Arrays in URLs are a mess, with languages varying in their support and formats accepted. Birdy previously only supported sending
(repeating key) style arrays in URLs. Now, it also supports comma (
URL spec needs to actually formally define how to represent URLs. Jeezâ€¦
Deepening personal learnings around duplex streams and streams in Node in general
